stem: A 28-year-old client with a tibia fracture reports worsening leg pain. Based on the documentation in the Orthopedic Manometry & Objective Perfusion Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Rule out compartment syndrome with objective pressure check.
Background: Massive crush injury to the right lower leg.
Assessment: Leg is tense and tight. Pain is 10/10 and not responding to Fentanyl.
Recommendation: Stryker needle manometry.

tabs.title: Manometry & Perfusion Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemFindingNotes
Anterior Compartment38 mmHgCritical (> 30)
Delta Pressure (MAP-P)12 mmHgLethal (< 30)
Skin TensionFirm; 'Wood-like'Mechanical obstruction
Radial PulsePalpable but weakArterial flow threatened

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 138/88, HR 112, RR 22, SpO2 98%. Hand/Foot is cool.

actionOptions.text: Prepare the client for an emergent fasciotomy.
Keep the extremity at the level of the heart (neutral position).
Apply a sequential compression device (SCD) to push out the fluid.
Administer STAT IV Heparin to treat the blockage.

parameterOptions.text: Intracompartmental pressure (mmHg) and Delta Pressure trends.
The 6 Ps (Pain, Paresthesia, Paralysis, Pallor, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia).
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose.
Presence of a positive Babinski sign.

rationale.correct: This is Acute Compartment Syndrome (c2), objectively verified by a Stryker manometry reading of 38 mmHg (Standard threshold for fasciotomy is > 30 mmHg or a Delta Pressure < 30 mmHg). Priority #1 is preparing for a fasciotomy (a1) to release the pressure before muscle necrosis occurs. Priority #2 is maintaining neutral heart-level positioning (a2) to ensure the best balance between arterial flow and venous return. Parameters focus on the objective pressures (p1) and standard clinical signs (p2).
clinicalPearls: Compartment pressure > 30 mmHg is the classic indicator that surgery is necessary.
Never put ice on compartment syndrome; it causes vasoconstriction and accelerates tissue death.
The 'P' of Pulselessness is a LATE sign; if you wait for it, the limb is likely already lost.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking a pressure of 38 is 'normal' because the BP is 138/88.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Compartment pressure is the INTERNAL pressure of the muscle. It should be close to zero. Once it goes above 30, it is strangling the tiny capillaries.
